data.title: Albert Camus’s Heart-Rending Romance with Another Woman

data.text:
Why does someone betray their partner? And why is it such a cliché that a married guy gets in bed with another woman?

When Albert Camus slept with María Casares, he was already famous while she had barely come of age. Oh yeah, he also had a wife and two kids.

Why didn’t he end the affair before things got out of control? Why did he keep on sitting on two chairs? If he couldn’t live without the girl, why didn’t he say goodbye to his wife then?

Was he a pathological narcissist? An insecure man who pretended to be a decadent intellectual? Who ends up misleading two loyal partners?

It can happen to anyone. There is something magnetic about adultery. You resist it until it sucks you in.

The Magnetic Attraction Between Camus and Casares

“On the morning of June 6, 1944, the Allies landed on the beaches of Normandy. That same night, Albert Camus and María Casares landed in bed together.” — Robert Zaretsky, LA Review of Books
